messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games is a story about young people who fight in a game.

In 2003 one night, Suzanne Collins watched TV.  
She changed channels a lot.  
The USA was at war with Iraq then.  
She saw two kinds of shows on TV.  
One was shows with real people.  
They tried to win a million dollars.  
The other was news about the war.  
These two things mixed in a scary way.  
Then the idea for The Hunger Games came to her.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8897 is below the required 0.90. The writer’s output replaces the specific term “reality programmes” with the vague phrase “shows with real people,” losing important lexical detail. It also summarizes “flipping between channels” as “changed channels a lot,” which weakens the original nuance. Suggestion: Restore key terms like “reality programmes,” keep “flipping between channels,” and ensure you retain the same level of detail and wording to meet the BERTScore threshold.

Detected deviations:

Suzanne Collins wrote it.

It was the time of the US invasion of Iraq.  
The only programmes she could find on TV were two kinds.  
One kind was competition shows.  
Young people competed to win one million dollars.  
The other kind was news about the war in Iraq.  
The two things start to merge together in a bad way.  
Then the idea for 'The Hunger Games' came to her.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text passes factual and meaning checks but fails A2 vocabulary requirements.
- The word "invasion" is B1-level and must be replaced with a simpler term like "attack" or "battle".
- The verb "merge" is C1-level; use "come together" instead.
- The connector "Then" may be too complex; use "After that" or split into two short sentences.
Suggestion: Replace all B1/C1 words with A2 equivalents, use only simple conjunctions (and, but, so, because), and keep sentences short.
